On 9/5/13 7:31 PM, uelverton@... wrote:
> I'm having a problem with heritrix in disc's usage. In the beginning of
> a crawl the disc's usage is low but it consumes a lot after some days.
>
> I noticed that the .jbd files increase really fast. For exemple:
>
>     # of .jdb |  Aug days
>     1171 16
>      260 17
>      607 18
>     1007 19
>     2222 20

>    37195 2

>    42417 4
>    42774 5
>
> I understood reading the forum and documentation (if not, correct me)
> that these files is part of the crawler's state and they keep olds uri
> to avoid repetition crawling. So, I just can't remove them but is there
> anything that could be done to avoid saving to much information for the
> deduplicator?

In the default setup, the JDB files (which support the Berkeley-DB-Java 
Edition database used by Heritrix) mainly track (1) the URIs 
already-seen; and (2) the ordered queues of URIs waiting to be fetched. 
(There are a few other things that are relatively quite small.)

If you change the crawler to sue something other the BdbUriUniqFilter, 
those files won't store (1). If you add other modules, they might also 
store other things among the JDB files.

In general all the data there is needed while the crawl is running (or 
if you want it to be resumable, or the source of URI data to be carried 
forward to a future re-crawl).

Note, though, that checkpoints keep extra JDB files around (via 
hard-links)... so if you're using checkpoints, and move past the time 
that you think you'd need to resume from a particular checkpoint, you 
could delete that checkpoint's directories (and thus discard unneeded 
JDB files).

I don't know what duplication-reduction options you may have enabled 
that could also be bloating things.

Most likely it's the growing size of your pending-URI queues that's the 
major contributor; if you can tighten your scope to ensure unwanted (or 
unlikely-to-ever-be-crawled) URIs are never enqueued, that'd help limit 
the on-disk growth.

- Gordon
